title: How much math is involved in electronics engineering? - Quora

response.answer_text: A lot like the following: Linear algebra - linear equations, matrices, eigenvalues, eigenvectors, etcNumerical methodsCalculus - limits, continuation, L’Hospital, Laplace transform, Fourier transform, etcComplex variables - Cauchy-Riemann, Line integral, Cauchy's integral theorem, Residue theorem, etcVector calculus - Gradient, divergence, Stokes, Gauss and Green's theorems, etcOrdinary differential equationsPartial differential equationsProbability and statisticsIn digital signal processing, controls systems, Z-transform, Discrete Laplace transform, Discrete Fourier transform are used quite extensively.

At about age 11 I got interested in a high-school chemistry book that had appeared in our house. Then I saw the statement in it to the effect that chemists had to know a lot of mathematics. Since I was having trouble with percentages in elementary school at the time, I put the book aside and turned my attention to electricity and electronics. Scan ahead 6 years and I’m ready to head off to university, studying electrical engineering. I meet with a family friend who is an electrical engineer. He says “electrical - that uses the most math of any branch of engineering”. I was mortifed - but it was too late to change. I managed to get through with average grades - then it didn’t matter any more.
